57 2/7/05   From: norskabird  To: mudbox44

I kinda get "the look" if I seem to be spending too much time here (got dial-up, so it's slow out here in the woods...). Actually, I just couldn't get to sleep so decided to see if some of my pals were up talking this late. It's nice and quiet at 11:30 so I can think and plan and just have some fun right here.

Sandi, you crack me up. You must have a lively office with you in charge!!! Keep up the good front...the computers will never know the difference...and WE SURE WON'T  TELL! Besides, you're learning all kinds of neat "stuff" right here. You're a natural!

Now, onward ho to the west!

norskabird

58 2/8/05   From: birdy2  To: 2live4

 

Hi Lana! Thanks for the reply. I am late getting on board because I left work at 4:30pm (central time) and went to Pensacola, Fl. to pick my car up. I had to have a new transmission (my 22 yr. old son can take credit for that!). I am one dumb cluck when it comes to horses. I LOVE to look at them & wish I knew about them. My friend has raised Tenn. Walkers for years. Back in his hay day he won the world championship. He has tons of ribbons & trophies all over the place. He is too old to ride now, but he still has people who train them & show them for him and he still wins. He had about 100 at Christmas time. He just sold 18 and bought another one. He told me he paid "a lot of money" sight unseen. It must have been a good line. He once told me he pays about $21,000 a month for their upkeep. I've seen him sell them at $40,000 a pop & the buyer was thrilled to get it for that price. Yes, he is rolling in money , but you'd never know it to see him. He shows them in Shelbyville, Tn.

I joined the local YMCA & hope to start my "trip to Morris" house this week. If you have time check out my ticker on the Milage Ticker thread. Wish we could come up with a way to show miles, etc. Have a good day tomarrow. Just having fun, Birdy

71 2/13/05   From: ndmmin  To: norskabird

Hi Norskabird and all;

I have to admit I am not really a football follower, but my husband does follow the Vikes. Can I still come along to Morris' place anyway? I just added up my milage tonight and since I started keeping track, I've gone a little over 20 miles! I might get there yet! Actually I was in the Twin Cities this weekend and spent most of Saturday outdoors at Como Park and other places. We even walked around an entire lake! (Well, OK, it was a small lake) 3 mile trip we estimated. It felt SOOOO good to get outdoors and walk on a 50+ degree February day. Spring will get here yet!

See you all at Morris' place.

Nancy

72 2/13/05   From: Bad Golfer  To: morris older

Hi Morris, I live just south of Seattle, so how far am I from you? I put in 4433 strides on the eliptical this morning...it said it was 3.75 miles. So how long will it take me to get to the party at that rate? I'm flying to Vegas next month to go to golf school so I can be good golfer instead of bad golfer. Maybe I should start out from there!!! And hooray...my a1c was 5.5 yesterday. My husband and the rest of my family just don't understand the signifigance of that, but I know everyone here will!

74 2/13/05   From: norskabird  To: ndmmin

Hi, Nancy. Gotta admit, we do follow the Vikes and would like to see them do a lot better than they do. But we're not particularly fans of their last 2 coaches, their quarterback or The Moss with The Mouth and The Attitude. But that would never stand in the way of your coming along! Football is mere child's play compared to what we're all dealing with. We need all the help and companionship we can get! I promise not to criticize your husband, either. I'm sure that in spite of his "weakness," he's a terrific fellow.

Which lake did you walk around? I used to live 2 blocks from Lake Harriet (2.8 mi. around) and walked it every day. Sure wish I had that lake near me now!! When you walk the lakes, you have a whole community of folks, and you see many of the same ones each day. After a while, you'll get a nod or a smile of recognition as you pass by from some of them.

It's snowing now down there in the Cities, and here, farther north, too. Our bare spots from last week's melting are already covered, and winter continues apace. I guess tomorrow I'll be walking my 3 miles on gravel on snowy gravel. It was cold today, but I made great time. But it's already February, so we're more than halfway through. I see the green grass on your ticker, and it raises my spirits every time!

75 2/13/05   From: norskabird  To: Bad Golfer

Hi, BadGolfer! I had my first trip to the state of Washington in Sept. '03 and LOVED it!! Loved Seattle. We sometimes talk about moving out there or Oregon, but I think we're pretty well wedded to our families here in MN.

CONGRATULATIONS on your 5.5! We do indeed understand what that means. Keep up the good work, however you got there. I see my doctor Tues. morning and will learn my latest a1c then. It was 7.1 at diagnosis in very early Dec. and 6.3 on Jan. 5th after a month of model eating and exercise. My endocrinologist wants it below 6.0, so your number would suit me just fine! Are you on any meds or are you managing it with diet and exercise? My doc said he'd give me 3 months to prove myself before he'd
consider putting me on meds, so I hope for a good report.

As for golfing badly...I've tried golf years ago and could never get the ball up in the air! It skittered along the ground real well, but I had to admit that I'm just not an athlete. I admire anyone who can play the game even passably! And yes, you could start from Las Vegas, I'd think. That will get you to Morris' before us Minnesotans, but if Morris had to wait for us, he'd be waiting too long. Just keep the red carpet handy for when we do show up.

76 2/14/05   From: mollythed  To: Bad Golfer

Hmmm.... 4433 strides in 3.75 miles = 1182.13 strides per mile on the elliptical machine.
Then 1182.13 strides times 680 miles (Seattle to San Francisco) = 803,848.4 strides to the Bay.

A lot less than 1,360,000 steps walking (figuring 2000 steps per mile).

Let's see.... Northfield, MN to San Francisco is about 1581 miles... If I carry my notebook computer in my red shopping cart, I can use it to keep track of my miles in an Excell spreadsheet.

77 2/14/05   From: morris older  To: Bad Golfer

Hi Bad Golfer,

congrats on the A1c 5.5, here we all understand how significant that is! I was up in Seattle for the second time in my life last year as my stepson lives there on an island in the sound--a beautiful , beautiful area! And he is bringing the 1.5 year old down next week for a visit, forestalling my winter visit to at least spring!

Unless you can make it all the way from Vegas before your return to Seattle, though I think you will have to count from Seattle. But bad golf or even good gulf can mean a lot of good walking--if you play enough rounds, what is 500 or so miles?

Anyway my guess is that you won't quite get here before you head back home, so at 3.75 miles per day, I calculate you will got the 810 miles between here and Seattle in 216 days. Of course YMMV (per day) but if that 3.75 is an average, you would get here on September 17, my brother's birthday. Maybe we can get him to come down from chico for a party and you can join in and then help prep the premises for the arrival of the diabetic army headed our way...

82 2/17/05   From: ndmmin  To: norskabird

going to be fun again.

On Sat. we walked around the Como Zoo and then went to Parker's Lake Park, in Plymouth, near my daughter's house and hiked  part of the bike trail there. Neat trail, on an old trail route, that goes for miles. Daughter said a co-worker bikes to work from her apt. in Minneapolis to job in Wayzeta. The Mom in me wonders if that is safe, though! I've never been to Lake Harriet, and thought about that on Sat. but thought it might be busier there. 83 2/17/05   From: norskabird  To: ndmmin

Hi, Nancy! CONGRATULATIONS ON TWO MORE POUNDS GONE!! And a size 12!!!!!!!!!! eeeyaaaaaaaaaahaaaaa! I can't wait to get there!

I have tons of clothes in sizes 8, 10 and 12 waiting for me. When I was married 13 yrs. ago, I had a beautiful size 12 suit, and I plan to get into that some time this fall. I looked really svelte then, so I can imagine how great you're looking now -and feeling, too!!! What a great reward, eh?

You'll notice, perhaps, that my wild ticker is gone and a new one in its place. I thought I'd try changing tickers when my weight changes. The great news today is that - overnight - I dropped 2 lbs. too!!! (I'd gained one since I put up the most recent ticker...) It's been SO SLOW - no loss last week at all - and I was having to work hard not to get too discouraged. I had picked up my exercise in the past few days, so evidently I needed to work even harder at that than I thought I was.

Anyway, I decided on the turtle because it represents the slow pace at which things are moving - and the music staff because I've been a musician all my life.

It's only 5 above here this morning, so I stayed in and did 40 minutes of aerobics. Hoping that my new Simmons stretch band comes today so that I can do that later this afternoon. Walking outside will have to wait. I envy you your trails all over the Cities, and one so close. I loved those kinds of walks when I lived there.

Again, congratulations! We'll keep up the good work!

norskabird

84 2/17/05   From: mollythed  To: ndmmin

 

. I know, for me, the first couple weeks are usually pretty easy, with good size drops, so I'm expecting to slow way down in the next couple weeks, even though I keep doing the same good things. The hard part is sticking with it, even without the encouraging big results, but that's the key to really making a change. Otherwise, the same pounds that came off easily in the beginning can come back just as easily.

85 2/17/05   From: morris older  To: ndmmin

Hi Nancy,

I am a member of the Rails to Trails Conservancy, and it sounds like the trails you mention might be on old rail lines. I have read that Minnesota is one of the leaders in converting them to trails. From what I have read they are generally pretty safe. We don't have too many of those around where I am, but I really do love the concept.

86 2/17/05   From: ndmmin  To: morris older
Hi Morris. Yes, I think Minnesota is one of the leaders in biking / hiking ( and snowmobile) trails, at least in the midwest.

The Heartland Trail, near us, links to some others and now if I had time ( and energy) I could bike almost to the east coast. I think there are a few parts that are not done, though. Eventually, it will link up to the west coast as well. Maybe after out trip to your place, we will have to walk that entire trail coast to coast. This is a great state to bike or hike in, wish I could do more of it.

Unfortunately, my husband won't bike with me. His urologist told him no biking after prostate surgery two years ago. I am trying to get him to visit a bike shop, becuase I think I have read that they do make specially shaped bike seats for men that are better for them. I'll keep trying.

THe trail I had mentioned earlier in another post was in Minneapolis and follows an old train line about 30 miles west. The reason I was wondering about safety was that is in actually in the "big city" and this country girl has trouble feeling that her daughter is always safe there when she's biking, or roller blading by herself!

Nancy

87 2/17/05   From: ndmmin  To: mollythed

back and start over.

I've been working on the weight since Dec. 8 and had the treadmill since the 20th of Dec., I think. I have always been a healthy eater, ( low fat, low salt, lots of fruit and veggies ) but now I am really watching the proportions, too and that plus the exercise sure does make a difference. I still am hungry and crave certain things sometimes, but it sure will be nice to get some new clothes, in a smaller size. That is a great incentive.

Oh, and I just read that you are a grandma now. How wonderful! I hope he lives close enough that you can see him all you want!

Nancy

88 2/17/05   From: morris older  To: ndmmin

HI Nancy,

I think I have read about the trail your daughter is using and the Heartland Trail as well. When trails like that are established, local property owners are often resistant because they think it will bring criminals into their neighborhood and lower their property values. But it has been shown over and over again that those trails, and actually trails in general,
foster community spirit and end up raising property values. The very people who packed hearings t oppose their creation sometimes end up being their bigger boosters once they have lived with them for a while.

89 2/17/05   From: Bad Golfer  To: norskabird

Hi Norskabird, I'm on diet and exercise, no meds. I was diagnosed in October and in December my A1C actually had gone up be a point. I almost started crying because I had been so good...eating right and hitting the gym 5 days a week. So, the doc gave me a little more time to get it down. Don't know why it went down. I'm doing all the same stuff. Maybe it just took a bit for the lifestyle changes to show up in the blood work. How did your test come back on Tuesday?

90 2/18/05   From: dershchu  To: loweezy

Hi can I come to Morris"house too . I live in upper New York about 30 miles from Canada. I love muffins and foot ball. I guess I have to start walking more or I could get left behind. We have a lot of snow right now can I ski part of the way or may be snow shoe. kimber

91 2/18/05   From: ndmmin  To: morris older

Morris: What is this group that you belong to about the trails? I think you need to come back here to the midwest and talk to some of these people about the benefits of trails. When I used to live in Iowa, it was quite a struggle to get the farmers to allow trails on the old rail beds, they wanted that land to plow. And even up here in Minn. there was an issue last fall with some land on the Paul Bunyan Trail where part of the trail was actually closed while the adjoining land owners went to court to sue for their land back. I'm not certain but I think the trail won that one. In the community I used to live in there was a wonderful plan for a trail from town out to a nearby lake which would have been the only trail within 25 miles, but again, the farmers and hunters won, so no trail. It wasn't even a money issue, since the committe had written and recieved grant money to pay for all the work. We here a lot around here about how to keep young people in our small rural communities, and i really think good recreational opportunities ( along with good medical care) is one of the most important ways to do that.

Maybe us T2s are just more aware of the benefits of good exercise than the anti-trail people! Oops, I think we are off the topic, but it is nice to find someone who really realizes the importance of these trails.

Nancy

92 2/18/05   From: Muzerof2  To: morris older

Hi Morris,

New to this board too. Everyone seems so friendly! My school too in NY was on strike in '68. What school did you go to?

Muz

93 2/18/05   From: morris older  To: ndmmin

Hi Nancy,

One of the trail groups I belong to is the Rails to Trails Conservancy, which is a national association of people supporting the conversion of old railroad rights of way to trails. They have recently set a goal that "by 2020, 90% of Americans will live within 3 miles of a network of public trails created from former trail lines and connecting corridors."

Membership contributes to that effort and carries the great benefit of a baurtiful and inspiring quarterly magazine describing such efforts around the country, and discussing the issues involved. Check out their web site at http://www.railtrails.org They are having a national conference in the Twin Cities in July.

94 2/18/05   From: morris older  To: Muzerof2

Hi Muz,

You are new to this board, but clearly you have been reading back a ways, because I hadn't posted that tidbit for I think months and only once. Anyway I was at Columbia back then, I'm not sure if any other schools were on strike in NY that year, although it became more widespread the next year--CCNY and NYU among others, just in the city.

99 2/22/05   From: lindameyer  To: 2live4

Hey Lana - I live in Buffalo (well actually, I live 20 miles south of Buffalo in the Town of Hamburg)!!! I want to meet at Morris's house too but have to figure out how far (not very good at doing that so it might take me a moment or two)

100 2/22/05   From: norskabird  To: Bad Golfer

Hi, Badgolfer! Thanks for asking about my last week's tests. My a1c was up from 6.3 to 6.5. After reading the article about a1c testing in the latest Diabetes Forecast, I'm not overly concerned about that, since the two tests were done in different labs. I just keep plugging along. My other readings were very encouraging: total cholesterol down to 195 for the first time ever (early Dec. it was 326!); LDL down to 107; HDL was down to 40 for some reason, from 47; the ratio between the two "DL's" was 5, which is max acceptable, but lower than it's been for years. So all in all, the report showed marked improvement in most areas. I had my Lipitor raised from 20-40 mg in early January, so between that and my proper eating and exercise, I guess things are working okay. I never cared so much about all those numbers!!

norskabird

101 2/22/05   From: 2live4  To: lindameyer

Hi Linda

Well I have been to Hamburg (the antique shop in your small quaint town). I could cross country ski to you. It would probably be Spring then (at the rate I go). Then we can throw on our sneakers and walk together. I live south of Rochester in Henrietta. I dont know how far it would be either...it is just very far.

Lana

102 2/28/05   From: lindameyer  To: All
 
Well, I am starting out for Morris' on March 1st at 5:00 a.m. EST. It's only 2,587.33 miles from Hamburg, NY to San Diego. Not sure exactly where Morris lives, but I will worry about that when I get closer. According to the local weather, might have to start out in some snow. Lana - how's the snow in Henrietta? Sounds like you might get more than us. Or have you started out already??

Also, based on someone else's calculations - of 2,000 steps per mile, I only have to walk 5,175,000 steps; if I do 10,000 steps a day, I will end up in San Diego in 517.4 days (that's if I walk 7 days a week). So based on those calculations, I will be there on July 31, 2006. See you all then!

103 2/28/05   From: norskabird  To: lindameyer

Lindameyer - oh, my gosh, I'm exhausted just thinking about it!!! Take good shoes, and if you find any kind of a red cart somewhere, pick it up and bring it along. Come to think of it, might we give you special dispensation to ski for a while? The experts say x-country racing burns more calories than any other sport, so why not?! 

Wish some of us were in the Rochester area to send you off with bells and whistles. I was born at Strong Memorial but left Rochester when I was 6 to head west to Ohio. Had cousins there who we visited yearly, and still have a 95-yr-old uncle there, so I have very fond feelings about the area. So - go west, young lady, go west, and we'll be there ta greet you on July 31, 2006. Boy, this is going to be some long party...!!!!!!!!!!! Morris, are you ready?????????

norskabird

104 2/28/05   From: morris older  To: norskabird

I am ready,NOrskabird, but I can save you a few miles, Linda--I am in Orinda, about 10 miles East of San Francisco.

So that may save you a couple of months on your trek cross country!

105 2/28/05   From: morris older  To: All

Hi all,

I was heading up with a group into the horse pasture Saturday as were moving to move the herd from one pasture to another--4,142 steps by the way, round trip--and as we walked up I cracked up some friends with my tale of an army of diabetics, honing their tickers, meeting at various rendezvous points, rooting for different football teams, pushing their red Target shopping carts full of diet soda (this was before I heard of the $400 worth of Tang --see the Vitamins and Diabetics thread for a great laugh) across Minnesota, all on their way to my house to eat banana muffins and see the horses
before continuing on to Hawaii.

Needless to say, there were numerous parts of t his story that my friends found quite amusing. As we approached the horses, one of them told me to write up the story and send it to that guy with the show on Saturday night--she couldn't remember his

name. On the way back, she remembered that she was talking about Garrison Keillor on Prairie Home Companion and pointed out what a natural it would be for him, with the Minnesota angle and all.

And actually I am tempted to do it, but only if you guys like the idea. I think this board is a wonderful place, and although I may be just egocentric enough to be swayed by the name or content of this thread, this diabetic migration is just crazy enough to encompass everything that is good about our on-line community here. At the same time, however, none of us who have contributed here had any thought of it going public, and so I would like to know what others think of this idea before I go ahead. If you guys have serious objections, based on privacy or anything else, well than I would have to respect that. But I think there is an opportunity to use this thread as an example of how people can help each other, how the diabetes world is changing, how bulletin boards are coming into their own, and all with a great sense of joy and humor. In fact here may even be more here than Prairie Home Companion can handle!

Please let me know what you think of this idea before I start thinking any further about how to proceed with it.

106 2/28/05   From: hap_hook  To: morris older

Hi Morris,

Been reading through this thread and have enjoyed what I've seen. One thing that has become obvious is that there will be a lot of folks heading for your place from the east. It might become necessary that they stop by my place first (Hayward area) and leave their cars here. I can also provide healthful beverages and emergency pit stops as needed! To get ready for the hike to Hawaii, we can do a practice trek across the Bay.

"Alright everybody!...Deep breath!...Hold it!...Down to the bottom!...Take a step!...Back to the surface!... Deep breath!...Hold it!...Down to the bottom!...Take a step!...

We can use the San Mateo Bridge bases for rest stops!

John

107 2/28/05   From: calbeach  To: morris older

An army of diabetics with their red shopping carts....you gotta love it! I have no objection. I once heard a speaker from AA say that alcoholism was too serious a disease to take seriously; I think that goes for the big D as well. For me, humor is as important as diet and exercise when it comes to coping with this illness.

108 2/28/05   From: calbeach  To: hap_hook
Somewhere (probably on America's Funniest Home Videos) I saw people walking on water on things that sort of looked like little boats crossed with snow shoes. So we can still go step by step, although the vision of "Alright everybody!...Deep breath!...Hold it!...Down to the bottom!...Take a step!...Back to the surface!... Deep breath!...Hold it!...Down to the bottom!...Take a step!...andis TOO funny. However, it seems to me that if we can make it to Morris', virtual walking on water with our shopping carts should be a cinch!

109 2/28/05   From: Timsma  To: morris older

Hey Morris ~ I love the idea! Now I'm envisioning all of us 'deep sea diving' along the way too! And then with our Target shopping carts on water yet! My family thinks I have gone nuts now as I am laughing hysterically! Too much of that expired Tang maybe??? I just hope we don't get caught shoplifting these red carts!!! We can be quick change artists tho and put our own name on them ~ they will never know then! You have my permission! ~ Kara

110 2/28/05   From: hap_hook  To: calbeach

I figured that I would have to do the step by step method. I get seasick as it is and I don't know how I would handle the snowshoe/little boats thingies! Maybe I can put waterwings on my motorcycle? But then, that would take the exercise away from the project! On the other hand, Hawaii is roughly 2510 miles from th S.F. Bay area. My fuel tank only holds enough fuel for about 250 miles (I haven't noticed any gas stations in the mid-Pacific). I don't think that I would like to push the darned thing 2260 miles over rough water!

Back to your idea! I guess that the virtual trek is the only practical route here!

John

111 2/28/05   From: Timsma  To: hap_hook

WOW ~ WHAT A VISION THAT IS!!!!!!!!!

NOW MY HUSBAND REALLY THINKS I'VE GONE LOONEY! AGAIN I AM LAUGHING HYSTERICALLY!!!

I'M PICTURING YOU PUSHING THAT CYCLE OVER THE ROUGH WATERS! TOOOOOO FUNNY! ~THANKS! ~ KARA

112 2/28/05   From: hap_hook  To: morris older

Hi Morris,

As a newbie to this site, I don't know how much my opinion matters. But this is one area where I do not think that there is much in the way that going public with the contents of this thread could cause anyone, that I have read, any possible harm.

As a prediabetic living with an insulin dependant diabetic, I have come to the realization over the years that diabetes is not something that is real important to keep hidden. It isn't like we are raising garter snakes in our derby hats! It is a disease that is becoming much more common, and treatable. The fact that many of us are able to deal with the situations we face and remain positive would be a good boost for those just starting to deal with the situation.

I really wish that my wife could look on her situation as most of the posters on this board do! It is a very serious condition that has to be rigidly maintained, but at the same time one must remain positive and keep a sense of humor going about this. If I had her attitude, I would be using at least Glucophage, if not insulin, by now. Instead, I chose to take mydfoctor's advice, monitor my blood sugar, watch my diet, and exercise. I've lost 48 pounds, reduced my reliance on antihypertensives, and eliminated (at least for the time being!) any medications for diabetes!

I am indeed blessed that I have been able to stave the condition off as long as I have. There is an extensive history of type 2 diabetes in my family history. So far I have gone longer without having to take medications for this than any other male in my family. I owe this to several people, besides seeing what my wife is going through, that encouraged me to take positive steps in taking care of myself at the onset of the pre-diabetes. The fact that they were much worse off than I was, and were good, fun-loving people had a very major impact on me! One of them told me that of all of the major illnesses that one could have to contend with, diabetes is one of the best. At least you can take positive steps to control the condition! Try doing that with something like congestive heart failure or cancer!

What ever the consensus is with this issue, you have my support. From what I have read of your postings, you are a sensible and sensitive individual. I am certain that whatever use this thread gets put to, it will be done with the proper attitude and taste.

John

113 2/28/05   From: mollythed  To: Timsma

No, we're not going to shoplift the carts. The idea is to get corporate sponsorship. I'm sure other states can find their own sponsors too. Sort of like auto racing.

114 2/28/05   From: Timsma  To: mollythed

PERIMENAUPAUSE THING ~ YEP, THAT'S WHAT I'LL BLAME IT ON! ~ KARA

118 3/1/05   From: lindameyer  To: All

Well, I started my journey at 5:20 a.m. (EST). I'm feeling I might be able to do more than 10,000 steps a day so might get there before next July! Anyway, its a good thing I started out this morning. The temp is in the 20's and although we got some snow during the night it isn't a hinderance. It actually looks quite beautiful on the pine trees and along the dead weeds in the fields. It's times like that when I absolutely love where I live and love the winter. Now, I need to hurry and get out of here because tomorrow is supposed to be windy with blowing snow and windchills of zero and below!

119 3/1/05   From: calbeach  To: hap_hook

John, I've been reading your posts elsewhere, as well as this one, and have great empathy for your situation. Your wife is very lucky to have you in her corner, and eventually she will realize that. Now, you said "It isn't like we are raising garter snakes in our derby hats!"

That's what our army of diabetics has been missing - hats! So, Morris, tell your friends we will be recognizable by our derby hats (hopefully the Minnesotans can pick some up for everybody at Target).

every week or so.

John

123 3/1/05   From: norskabird  To: All

Yumpin' yimminy, I know so many Ole end Lena yokes, I could tell 'em all da vay across da country! Dey all begin, "Did ya hear duh vun about..." Ya, shur, you betcha!!

Molly, if yew ken only get dem Viking caps, I'll vear vun yust to keep harmony among da Minnesota grewp. I don't hate dem Vikings, I yust don't favor dem so much.

Target sponsorship sounds pritty good tew me. I got a distant relative dat verks fer dem, so mayhap I could get him on da ball. Good luck goin' in circles vile yew vait fer da rest of us comin' along in da spring. It's March now! Ken spring be far avay??!!! (Ja, yew bet!)

Alla yew out dere in sunny California...ve ken't vait tew see yew all vaving tew us from da beach! Here's tew a lotta laughs!!!

norskabird

128 3/1/05   From: hap_hook  To: norskabird

Yah-huh! Got more den I barguned fer vit the Ole and Lena - you betcha! Vas serious 'bout the lefsa thou. Can't get it here in Calif. (At least I haven't been able to find it. When I want it I have to make it myself! If you are ready for this...A Scots-Irish making lefsa! Yes Harriet, I do eat lutafisk as well...) If you bring the Viking Caps with you, Don't wear them

around Hegenberger and I880 in Oakland! It could be hazardous to your health! (Approximate location of the "Black Hole" of the Raiders fans! Dem bullet caps vit da' horns sure makes dem guys crazy! Uf da!)

It seems that I need to address an misunderstanding on my part. I got the impression that Morris lived in San Francisco. I guess that I am mistaken. I hear that he lives further east. It now appears that my place will be the last pit stop prior to the trek to Hawaii! After my place we get to practice by walking across the bay, and then we get to the hills on the
peninsula, and then we get to the Pacific. Make sure that you bring you hooded sweatshirts to wear over your Hawaiian Flowerty shirts. The Pacific this far north is VERY, VERY COLD! People have been known to turn blue in mid summer. Especially after going into the water!

Morris

Diagnosed Type 2, with an A1c of 11.4 in 2003; averaging a 5.0 A1c since then with diet, exercise and Glipizide XL + meds for blood pressure and cholesterol.  A bit dated, but scroll down on this page if you want to know more ...

‎08-09-2011 11:01 PM

I remember walking to Morri's House!

It has been years since I have been here, the place has changed and once again the ole lady is totally lost here so if you find me, direct me in the right direction of where ever I should be. Now I gotta figure out where I am and how to get there. I can get lost going around the block. And when I get bored at work I go exploring on the net (hey work is done lol)and usually end up in the land of diabetes sites. go figure

I am gayle a very young woman of almost 65 years, have had diabetes for about 16 years, very compulsive about my health, tho my doctor finds me amusing the way I am lol. I am in control and have been for years, well then the ole thyroid got jealous of the attention I was given to the other two organs so it decided to misbehave and could not just be a normal hyperactive,no had to give me Graves disease which at my age is not as common, but then I am not the normal person. So anyhoo dove right back in and got everything back into control...body acting like a bunch of spoiled kids.

And I could not find a introduce yourself so here I am...but in a nutshell - married, still work full time, reside in New Hampshire, owned by several furbabies, crochet and gardening for relaxing,  on metformin and exercise...and yes I still eat chocolate, and once in a while icecream and pizza !

Now to go figure out where the heck Morris' house is
